title: Major UN climate change report gets approval after Saudi objections
text:
A major UN report detailing how global warming is wrecking Earth's oceans and ice will be published in part tomorrow after members approved it.

The special report by the Intergovernmental Panel for Climate Change (IPCC) was finalised in an all-night debate yesterday.

Saudi Arabia had been obstructing the process by taking issue with the inclusion of a report which predicted the effects of a 1.5°C (34.7°F) average global temperature rise.

But the oil-rich nation was finally satisfied last night and the IPCC said it would go ahead with the report about oceans and the cryosphere – the Earth's icy regions.

The IPCC report is expected to warn that melting ice caps will cause sea levels to rise so much that around 280million could be displaced from their homes if global temperatures rise by an average of 2°C (35.6°F). (Pictured: Antarctica)

'So, after 27 hours of continuous work overnight, we got #SROCC approved by Governments! Elation, relief, exhaustion, emotion. Hard to describe. I just hope this bloody thing does some good for the world,' tweeted Michael Meredith, one of the report's authors.

Officials from 195 countries had to sift through and approve every line of a 30-page executive summary of the report, which is set to be published tomorrow.

The study will warn that climate change is going to trigger huge increases in flooding damage, melting ice caps and glaciers, and coral-killing ocean heatwaves.

A leaked early draft of the report suggested that, if global temperatures rise by an average of 2°C (35.6°F), 280million people could be displaced by rising sea levels.

And melting permafrost – permanently frozen earth – will release huge amounts of greenhouse gases into the atmosphere, creating a cycle of warming.

One of the scientists who wrote the report, Michael Meredith, said: 'I hope this bloody thing does some good for the world'

Saudi Arabian officials had refused to give their approval for part of the report because it included part of another study they didn't agree with.

This one suggested a rise of even 1.5°C would be catastrophic for the Earth and said drastic cuts were needed to the use of fossil fuels.

The country, which is the world's largest exporter of oil, has raised similar objections to IPCC reports in the past.

One unnamed member of the UN meeting in Monaco told AFP: 'It really seems like Saudi Arabia only came to this meeting to block any language on 1.5C.'

The 2015 Paris Agreement, signed by 196 nations, called on countries to try and prevent global temperatures from rising by any more than 2°C, or 1.5°C if possible.

AFP reported that the sentence to which the Saudis objected – 'This assessment reinforces findings in IPCC Special Report on 1.5 C' – was removed from the final draft.

Jean-Pierre Gattuso, a French scientist involved in writing the report, tweeted: 'Gaveled! The Special Report on the #Ocean and #Cryosphere #SROCC is approved! A delightful moment at this early morning hour, after 2 years of work and a session of more than 27 h.'

Jean-Pierre Gattuso, one of the scientists who contributed to the report, said it was a 'delightful moment' when all the countries finally agreed on the summary's wording
description: Officials from Saudi Arabia, the world's biggest exporter of oil, had taken issue with one of the reports referenced in the study which will reveal the extent of devastation to the world's oceans.
